name: 2-(4-chlorophenyl)indole
Reason: The target compound 2-(4-chlorophenyl)indole, contains several distinct structural elements influencing its melting point: the indole unit, the phenyl ring, and chlorine substituents. The melting point of indole itself is 52 degrees Celsius. Each aromatic ring tends to increase the melting point due to the stable pi-stacking interactions, which here would include the fused benzene-pyrrole ring of the indole (we can estimate +50 for the additional aromatic character) and another +30 for the additional phenyl ring. Each chlorine atom contributes further to increasing the melting point through its inductive effect and contributes to the overall rigidity and symmetry of the molecule, which is generally associated with the increase of the melting point; estimate +20 per chlorine. Based on these approximations, the prediction can be calculated as follows: 52 (indole base) + 50 (extra aromaticity and stability from the fused system) + 30 (additional phenyl group) + 40 (two chlorine substituents) = 172 degrees Celsius.

name: 2-(4-chlorophenyl)indole
Reason: The base structure of indole has a melting point of 52°C. The addition of a fused benzene ring to form the indole compound contributes significantly to the rigidity and packing of the molecule, which can be quantitatively estimated to increase the melting point by approximately 50°C. Furthermore, the extra phenyl ring, due to additional pi-stacking and van der Waals interactions, would also increase the melting point by an estimated 30°C. Each chlorine substituent, with its electron-withdrawing properties, increases intermolecular forces due to polarizability and adds to molecular symmetry, which can be estimated to increase the melting point by about 20°C each. Therefore, the total estimated effect on the melting point would be 52 (for indole) + 50 (for the extra fused benzene) + 30 (for the phenyl group) + 40 (for two chlorine substituents) = 172°C.

name: 2-(4-chlorophenyl)indole
Reason: The basic unit for this compound can be considered to be indole, which has a melting point of about 52°C. The phenyl group typically raises the melting point due to increased planarity and π-π interactions, estimated at +40°C per phenyl. The chloro substituents are electron-withdrawing and enhance the rigidity of the molecule, which increases the melting point. Each chloro substituent can be estimated to increase the melting point by about +30°C. The compound has two chloro substituents and one additional phenyl group. Therefore, the increase in melting point is calculated as follows: Basic indole unit: 52 + Phenyl group: +40 + 2x Chloro substituents: 2x30 = +60.

name: 2-(4-chlorophenyl)indole
Reason: The compound 2-(4-chlorophenyl)indole contains multiple functional groups that influence its melting point. The basic unit, which is indole, has a melting point of about 52 degrees Celsius. The effects of the functional groups are as follows: - Benzene rings: +40 each (the π-π stacking and increased molecular rigidity elevate the melting point). Since there are two benzene rings, this effect is doubled. - Chlorine substituents: +60 each (they introduce dipole-dipole interactions and increase molecular weight). As there are two chlorine atoms, this will be combined. - NH group: +20 (hydrogen bonding capabilities). Summing up all these effects: 52 (indole base) + 2 × 40 (2 benzene rings) + 2 × 60 (2 chlorine substituents) + 20 (NH group).

name: 2-(4-chlorophenyl)indole
Reason: The compound 2-(4-chlorophenyl)indole consists of an indole base structure fused with a benzene ring that contains chloro substituents. Each structural aspect influences the melting point. Indole alone has a base melting point of 52 degrees Celsius. Incorporating the effects of the functional groups yields the following: - Indole base melting point: +52 - Additional benzene ring: +30 (due to increased molecular rigidity and π-π interactions) - Chlorine substituents: +20 each (due to electronegativity, which leads to stronger dipole-dipole interactions, and a slight increase in molecular weight) - NH group: +15 (due to the potential for hydrogen bonding, which raises the melting point) Adding these contributions to the indole melting point, the estimated value is found: 52 (indole) + 30 (additional benzene) + 2 × 20 (two chloro groups) + 15 (NH group).
